description.narrative: Increased familiarity among diverse stakeholders with EE lighting and associated issues

Awareness of general public about advantages of EE lighting, rating and labeling systems for lighting, and proper handling of spent mercury-containing lamps, as measured by quantitative scoring of survey data
Coverage of outreach campaigns, in terms of population

comment.narrative: Not defined quantitatively. General public widely disregards advantages of EE lighting. Rating/labeling systems and mercury-lamp collection programs for general public do not exist.

Outreach campaigns conducted, reaching 6.5 million citizens. Forty percent of overall population is aware of advantages of EE lighting, rating and labelling systems for lighting, and proper handling of spent mercury-containing lamps

The project has totally 5 videos. 2013 – 2 videos made, one video promotes mercury utilization, and another video shows advantages of energy efficient lighting. These videos were actively promoted in 2014. The utilization video was rotated in the cinemas of «Kinopark» label, afterwards Astana municipality helped to show this video on TV. Currently the video is shown in Astana public places, such as railway stations, buses, center for people services, etc. The video is posted on youtube, also it is shown during project events. In the period of 2013-2014 when it was actively promoted it covered about 600 thous.people. In 2014-2015 it covered about 200 thous. people. Up to date it totally covered 800 thous.people.
The extended video about various advantages of energy efficient lighting was submitted to the MINT (now Ministry for investment and development) which helped to have it shown on state channels. Currently it is promoted during project events. 2013-1014 – the video covered 600 thous.people; 2014-2015 – 100 thous.people, totally – 700 thous.people covered.
Two videos made, 3D video and a cartoon. The cartoon shows the lighting evolution, and the 3D video talks about energy saving and EE lighting. The videos are promoted on the internet. Also there were made EE lighting awareness installations which then were distributed among project partners. The Project Facebook page is regularly updated and has a growing number of followers and viewers The Project always participated in contests related to energy saving ideas promotion. Totally printed materials distribution covered about 10 thous.people:
2012-2013 – 1 thous. people. 2013-2014 – 7 thous people. 2014-2015 – 2 thous.people.
In 2014 there were made PR events in various cities of Kazakhstan in the form of installing informational stands in city squares, during those events people were informed about EE lighting and were given project printed materials. The events took place in Astana, Almaty, Atyrau, and Aktau in August-September, 2014.
Six press-briefings were given in Astana, Atyrau, Aktau, and Semey in the period of June-November, 2014.
The project regularly conducts media-trainings for journalists regarding use of multi-media tools when discussing issues of energy efficiency. In 2014 media-trainings were made in Ust-Kamenogorsk, Kyzylorda, and Aktau. In 2015 in Eastern and Southern Kazakhstan two media-trainings were carried out. In 2015 media-trainings were given in Kyzyorda, Shymkent, and Aktau.
TV shows: In 2015 in three regions of the country (Aktau, Shymkent, Kyzylorda) the project experts participated in the TV talk-shows to discuss energy saving and energy efficiency.
Totally seminars, media-trainings, and TV shows covered about 400 thous.people, 2013-2014 – 250 thous.people, 2014-2015 – 150 thous.people.
Trainings were given to trainers of energy auditors according to study module for energy audit of lighting systems in buildings, structures, and street lighting. The project participated in the training seminars for energy managers in Energy Efficiency Centers (about 500 people covered). 2013-2014 – 350 people. 2014-2015 – 150 people.

description.narrative: Increased investor confidence, design and administrative capacity, and market share of EE lighting as a result of demonstration projects
Energy savings and GHG emissions reductions from EE upgrades of lighting in selected public buildings or street-lighting projects

comment.narrative: Outdated lighting technology is widely used in both buildings and street lighting. Quantitative baseline parameters to be determined during design phase for each specific project.
31,000 tons of direct avoided CO2 emissions over operating lifetime of deployed demonstration technology. Specific technical and economic performance targets to be determined for each project.

Project had modernized street lighting systems in 5 pilot areas within Kazakhstan: Northern, Eastern, Western, and Central regions. Energy efficient LED lighting equipment with automatic control was installed. Power saving is 5 961 MWt/h which shall prevent from 5550 CO2 emission from fuel combustion used for power generation.
Together with the Project and the new Joint Program of the UN and Mangistau and Kyzylorda oblasts the lighting was modernized in schools. Demonstration projects include lighting modernization of the 41 classrooms in 4 schools of Kyzylorda and Mangistau.
Powert saving is 2 976 MWt/h which shall prevent from 2 775 ??2 emission from fuel combustion used for power generation. Total GHG emissions reduction amounted to 10 850 tons ??2

description.narrative: Replication of demonstration project results, in terms of number of projects, number of regions, and amount of financing mobilized

comment.narrative: Business-as-usual does not reflect practices that are to be applied in demonstration projects
Replication of demonstration project results in at least five projects in five regions At least $12 million invested in EE lighting projects

Funds were assigned from the local budget in:
Eastern-Kazakhstan oblast: 420 modern LED lighting fixtures were installed in Ust-Kamenogorsk for the roadway lighting. In 2014 all over Eastern-Kazakhstan oblast 13 884 energy saving lighting fixtures were installed for the amount of 4,1 mln dollars.
In Pavlodar oblast among 30 250 street lighting fixtures more than 11 thousand or 35% were changed to energy saving types for the amount of 3,3 mln dollars. Also 28 sets of automated street lighting were installed for the total amount of 23 000 dollars.
In Northern-Kazakhstan oblast there was installed and set the automated system for street lighting control through the GSM network covering 40% of the capacity. 400Wt mercury lighting fixtures were completely replaced with the 250 Wt energy saving types. The economic saving for a year was 20 000 dollars. In oblast 55% of all the street and park lighting was replaced with the energy saving lamps.

description.narrative: NIP update, integration of POPs into national planning and promoting sound healthcare waste management in Kazakhstan

title.narrative: NIP update, integration of POPs into national planning and promoting sound healthcare waste management in Kazakhstan

description.narrative: To reduce the releases of uPOPs and other globally harmful pollutants into the environment by promoting sound HCWM in Kazakhstan, to assist the country in implementing its relevant obligations under the Stockholm Convention.
Energy - policy, planning and administration

To reduce the releases of unintentionally produced POPs and other globally harmful pollutants into the environment by promoting sound healthcare waste management in Kazakhstan, and to assist the country in implementing its relevant obligations under the Stockholm convention.
Update of the National Implementation Plan (NIP) on Stockholm Convention is prepared and coordination on chemical MEAs is enhanced.

comment.narrative: No inventory on new POPs Fragmented legislation controls NIP not updated Several POPs initiatives are implemented not in a coordinated way
Inventory completed and publicly available NIP obligations with inclusion of new POPs reviewed and updated. Updated draft NIP is presented to the Government for review process and endorsement

Overall, six (6) consultation meetings held at four (4) general workshops on POPs (and in combination with mercury aspects), and two (2) at the premises of Ministry of Energy organized by UNDP during September –November 2014. An inventory on the use and import of new POPs has been completed, while work on unintentional POPs, and planned work on updated inventory on POPs pesticides are still ongoing. The update on new POPs to NIP was approved by order of the Minister of Energy of the Republic of Kazakhstan 228 dated 30.12.2014 and submitted to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to be presented to the Secretariat for the Stockholm Convention. National register on POPs establishing their maximum allowed emissions (based on a new decree of the Ministry of Energy – where environmental branch is now attached to – no. 26 dated 25 January 2015) has been created. Previous Resolution of the Government in this respect was outdated and approved in 2007. Current legislative system (after reform) in the country is operated on the basis of branch decrees taken by respective line Ministries, and is regulated overall by the Djasyl Damu (Green Economy) Programme of National Development. Additionally, amendments on mandatory environmental monitoring of unintentional POPs (dioxins/furans) releases have been proposed to the Ecological Code as part of the Green Economy’s programme amendments.

description.narrative: Mercury inventory and Reduction plan prepared.

comment.narrative: Stand-alone, site specific mercury contamination remediation programme is in place by the World Bank No other inventories of mercury initiated and completed and human exposure estimated No mercury use and release standard set No national mercury management plan formulated and approved

Mercury situation in Kazakhstan assessed Inventory is documented Inter-agency consultations held National capacity to handle recovered mercury is assessed and recommendations for improvement are set forward Draft National Mercury Reduction Plan developed with identified priorities. Mercury emission standard established.

An initial assessment of the existing capacity for the management of mercury has been carried out with support of a selected and sub-contracted national consultancy firm “Centre for Facilitation of Sustainable Development”. Main sources of mercury pollution have been identified, and a list of companies engaged in recycling and treatment of mercury waste has been prepared. However, the MIA project is able only to provide an overview of the mercury situation, and larger investments will be required in future for full assessment of mercury emitters, An assessment of the current legislation on mercury handling has been carried out and recommendations for legislative additions/revision have been provided. The Ministry of Energy in cooperation with local authorities continues to work to remediate a historical mercury hotspot in Pavlodar city (population of 352 693 as of start of 2014), and a WB-supported project in Karaganda was to complete on Nura river contamination.
An inter-agency working group on mercury management, involving Ministries of Foreign Affairs, Industry and Trade, Health, Economy and Social Development, and representatives of industrial associations, was established in January 2015 to support consultations and decision-making on joining the Minamata Convention. A capacity building program on creating awareness on the risks of the use and release of mercury in the environment; conducting an inventory; identifying sources of mercury emissions; and creating a release database, has been developed. Four (4) training sessions were delivered on mercury issues (within same series of POPs related regional conferences) as faced by hospitals during the medical waste management: three (3) in October 2014 in Kostanay, Astana, and Ust-Kamenogorsk (250 people), and one (1) larger workshop in September 2014 (50 people). Justification concept on Minamata convention ratification drafted and is prepared for submission to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs for review.

description.narrative: POPs emissions from healthcare waste incineration are reduced through a demonstration component, and wider replication of results.

comment.narrative: Waste segregation for waste source reduction is not a standard accepted approach in medical facilities Routine waste incineration without emission controls and risk reduction measures is commonly practiced Low level of practical knowledge and use of non-combustion techniques Baseline emissions constitute 124.88 g TEQ/a to air, and 0.65 g TEQ/a to bottom ash.

Mid-term:
Releases reduced to 86.08 g TEQ/a to air, and 0.46 g TEQ/a to bottom ash. End of project:
Releases reduced to 16.38 g TEQ/a to air, and 0.11 g TEQ/a to bottom ash

Three (3) pilot areas selected for demonstration of alternative non-combustion technologies in treatment of healthcare wastes as a replacement of existing basic incinerators with no installed stack air cleaning systems. These are Kostanay, Astana (capital) and Ust-Kamenogorsk provinces. An assessment of the waste generation volumes and decontamination of infectious healthcare waste across the country as a whole has been completed. And, in selected pilot areas this assessment has been implemented in all 8 in-patient medical facilities. For a number of selected incinerators (1 in pilot Kostanay province, and 2 in Ust-Kamenogorsk province, as Astana authorities declined on tests), exemplar stack emission tests were conducted. Dioxin and furan emissions exceeded the EU established maximum allowable concentrations (MACs) on average by 28 times. Based on technical advice from international expert, the project team had designed Healthcare Waste Management Plans for three selected pilot areas (Kostanay, Astana, and Ust-Kamenogorsk). These plans include description of currently used healthcare waste management system, proposed alternative ways to improve practices through waste segregation (including the use of needle cutters to reduce accidents at work, and separate out plastic parts for disinfection). The use of needle cutters to allow for the segregated collection of sharps (metal) and separation of remaining plastic parts of the healthcare waste has been set in the legislation (Decree of Ministry of Health, no. 127 dated 24 February 2015). Same decree provided for use of alternative methods for healthcare waste treatment. Four (4) workshops were held, as described in the previous section, to raise awareness of government agencies and medical facilities about alternative ways for healthcare waste treatment (300 people).

description.narrative: Mercury waste generated by the health sector is managed soundly and future waste is minimized

comment.narrative: Broken thermometers: 236.81 kg/a.

Mid-term:
Releases reduced to (in broken thermometers): 210.81 kg/a. End of project:
Releases reduced to 200 kg/a
Planned in the next reporting cycle

description.narrative: POPs inventories improved for informed decision making and priority setting
Capacity building programme (trainings) for involved stakeholders developed and implemented on POPs risks, inventories, POPs tracking, monitoring of data reported by responsible parties.

comment.narrative: Training on PCBs inventory and management is being carried out in the framework of the UNDP PCB project. No training on new POPs is currently planned on POPs issue in Kazakhstan Limited information on new POPs is available

Training program on POPs risks and their sound management has been prepared with help of contracted consultancy firm “Centre for facilitating Sustainable Development”. This program will be placed on a web-link of consolidated training and awareness resources on sustainable development hosted under the National Development Programme “Djasyl Damu – Green Economy”. In addition, it and other project’s produced materials, will be placed in the Ministry of Energy’s Information and Analytics Centre which is involved in career enhancement education activities for staff members. Other trainings included the central authority related training, which engaged industrial enterprises, on POPs inventorying which was held in September 2014. This was planned to easy access to date from industrial sector. During reporting period, the project team together with territorial municipalities and health authorities had selected future project sites – the sites where new alternative technology (non-incineration) will be installed for demonstration purposes. These sites are located in: Kostanay (north-west), Astana (capital, centre-north), and Ust-Kamenogorsk (east) provinces. Three (3) trainings arranged in these three (3) regions – at selected pilot sites - for 250 people from territorial municipal, health, sanitary and environmental control authorities. Additional main workshop held in September 2014 in Astana for central authorities, and representatives of industry. Topics of these trainings included risks of POPs, POPs monitoring, institutional roles and responsibilities, legislation for the control of POPs and measures for its implementation. Measuring training effectiveness is planned for future reporting cycles Data on new POPs collected and assessed, and formed an update request to the NIP, with follow-up transmission of this information to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs and later on to the Stockholm Convention Secretariat. This has been achieved by statistics and import database searches, requests for information to industrial and private sectors, company visits, etc.

description.narrative: National information system (inventory) on POPs expanded (updated information on uPOPs and new POPs).

comment.narrative: ·Original 2003-2005 uPOPs inventory conducted with a limited set of industrial sources and outdated. Inventory of POPs pesticides stockpiles and burial sites limited to 20% of the country at the NIP stage. Under the sectoral programs “Zhasyl Damu (Green Growth) for 2010-2014”, adopted by the Government of the Republic of Kazakhstan dated September 10, 2010 # 924, a detailed inventory of all POPs and obsolete pesticides is envisaged but not started yet.

uPOPs inventory completed using the most recent data available. POPs inventories updated for uPOPs and POPs pesticides, covering all the territory of Kazakhstan. Industrial use of new POPs identified and possible chemical and non-chemical alternatives assessed. Inventory of stockpiles and burial sites of pesticides covering at least 70% of the country. Plan for maintaining and completing the above inventories elaborated and institutional responsibilities assigned. An information system on inventories of POPs substances established

Preparatory works performed for the determination of the main sources of unintentionally produced POPs, works on further inventory of uPOPs are planned. Based on open tender, a national consultancy firm “Centre for Facilitation of Sustainable Development” was selected and sub-contracted to support national level activities. Overall, four (4) national experts have been engaged in the process of NIP update. This work was supported by an international expert to guide the process. Preparatory works have been undertaken to determine the main sources of unintentionally produced POPs; works on further inventory of uPOPs are planned. Inventory on new POPs has been completed, while work on unintentional POPs, and planned work on updated inventory on POPs pesticides are still ongoing. Data on new POPs have been captured in the NIP update document which was transmitted to the Stockholm Convention secretariat. NIP update for new POPs was approved by order of the Minister of Energy of the Republic of Kazakhstan 228 dated 30.12.2014 and submitted to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to be presented to the Secretariat for the Stockholm Convention. Project manager is an invited member to and regularly participates in a decision-making board of the Ministry of Energy on installation of a national hazardous waste disposal plant (HTI – high temperature incineration) in Kazakhstan where future POPs stockpiles can be safely disposed of in line with international best practices. Information on POPs pesticides in particular will be useful to help Kazakhstan remove these wastes in future when the plant is in operation, and this also provides a feedback mechanism on inventories to the Ministry of Energy. The main industries that use new POPs have been identified. These sectors include agriculture, engineering, light industry and pharmaceutical industries. National register on POPs establishing their maximum allowed emissions (based on a new decree of the Ministry of Energy – where environmental branch is now attached to – no. 26 dated 25 January 2015) has been created.

description.narrative: National capacities on POPs monitoring, analytical capabilities are assessed
Studies on existing POPs analytical and monitoring capabilities for the whole range of POPs (with focus on new POPs) carried out

comment.narrative: A few laboratories identified in the course of NIP preparation and GEF/UNDP PCB management programme. Laboratories are currently only nationally accredited for PCB analyses Draft POPs national monitoring plan developed by RECETOX – a Stockholm Convention’s Regional Centre in the Czech Republic.
National POPs monitoring plan approved as part of relevant national policies and documents. Participation in regional monitoring networks.

Existing laboratory capacity has been assessed. About nine (9) laboratories have the potential to determine uPOPs in the various environmental media, provided methodologies are provided and accreditation is supported to enable full commercial activity. Two (2) laboratories were identified/selected to receive project support for national accreditation. Maximum allowable emissions for dioxins and furans have been set by Decree of Ministry of Energy # 26 of January 21, 2015. Further, amendments have been proposed by the project in terms of a law on introducing requirements on POPs monitoring in environment into existing regulatory framework associated with the implementation of the Djasyl Damu (Green Economy) National Development Programme. A capacity building program on POPs risks, undertaking a POPs inventory and monitoring of POPs has been developed. This is based on bilateral assistance from UNDP-Czech Trust Fund deployed before in the GEF-UNDP PCB management programme in Kazakhstan. The RECETOX (Brno, Czech Republic based laboratory of regional importance) is a partner selected for this activity. While training will be provided by RECETOX, the project will support travel of 15 laboratory staff. The following laboratories will participate: Central Sanitary-Epidemiological, KazHydroMeteorological, Central Environmental and private laboratories. Participation in regional laboratory networks is possible after capacity building part is complete, and national accreditation is in place.

description.narrative: A set of recommendations for the improvement of such capabilities formulated and submitted to the Government

comment.narrative: No full range of POPs and POPs in goods/environment is handled by existing laboratories No national consultations held on priorities No action plan is in place for improvements
At least two (2) laboratories accredited to perform uPOPs analysis in goods/environment;

Laboratories to be prepared for accreditation are determined. POPs monitoring activities can only be implemented once appropriate training and capacity building to national laboratories have been delivered, and further supported by additional support in terms of applicable methods and accreditation processes. A training workshop is planned for laboratories with help from the regional POPs laboratory located in Brno, Czech Republic at premises of the Masaryk University. This laboratory is a designated regional POPs service center (approved by the COP of the Stockholm Convention in 2008) for Europe and Central Asia region. The Concept of Transition of Kazakhstan to the Green Economy (GE) – Djasyl Damu included general reference to air pollution by dioxins (section 3.6). The Action Plan to implement the Concept of GE included a measure to ensure strengthening of the technical capacity of regional analytical laboratories to obtain reliable operational data on the pollution of surface and groundwater, soil and air in order to undertake rehabilitation and preventive measures, identification and study of pollution areas originating from landfills in order to identify areas in need of cleaning and rehabilitation.

description.narrative: Policy, institutional frameworks and enabling regulatory environment are in place to ensure better control on POPs accumulation and emissions
Institutional coordination and compliance with international agreements improved through firmer institutionalization of POPs issues into national structures

comment.narrative: No POPs coordination center in existence due to lengthy Government’s approval procedures and unaligned MEP mandate, and mismatch of proposed workplans (to 2028) with 3 year long financial planning processes POPs coordination happens in a fragmented manner with no alignment of roles Nu funding sources to sustain POPs coordination function are available

POPs group meets regularly to guide the NIP update process Institutionalization of new POPs issues into relevant line ministries ensured according to defined roles. Coordination mechanisms on POPs issues institutionalized and embedded into draft regulations sent for Government’s review and approval Funding sources to ensure the mechanism’s sustainability are defined, consulted on with MoF, and proposed for inclusion in national planning

According to the Minutes of the Meeting with the Minister of Energy from 29 June 2015 (# 19-01-01-01/101) the establishment of a working group on POPs management issues is currently planned to become a dedicated group on national POPs management issues. Project manager is an invited member to and regularly participates in a decision-making board of the Ministry of Energy on installation of a national hazardous waste disposal plant (HTI – high temperature incineration) in Kazakhstan where future POPs stockpiles can be safely disposed of in line with international best practices. The development of proposals for the institutional structure of public authorities and organizations responsible for the implementation of the three conventions (Basel, Rotterdam and Stockholm) are planned by the project team in consultations with relevant stakeholders. It is also planned to identify measures to assist the work of the state bodies on the implementation of the three Conventions.

description.narrative: National legal framework, by aligning institutional roles, reviewed and improved to include the issue of insofar unaddressed POPs, uPOPs and new POPs

comment.narrative: Ecological Code contains only general information on POPs management (chapter 40 on dangerous chemicals), with amendments related to PCBs supported by GEF/UNDP programme on PCBs The Government has plans to extend the provisions of chapter 40 to regulate emissions uPOPs MEP plans measures to improve the operational control of industrial emissions, including burning of fuels, and promote the construction and modernization of facilities for cleaning exhaust gases in the steel industry.
Final report on the improvement of current regulatory system for including the issues of insofar unaddressed POPs, uPOPs and new POPs. Amended regulation drafted and submitted.

National register on POPs establishing their maximum allowed emissions (based on a new decree of the Ministry of Energy – where environmental branch is now attached to – no. 26 dated 25 January 2015) has been created. Previous Resolution of the Government in this respect was outdated and approved in 2007. In addition, maximum allowable concentration of dioxins in the air of populated areas has been defined in sanitary regulations # 168 called "Sanitary-epidemiological requirements to air quality in urban and rural areas, soils and their safety, content areas of urban and rural settlements, conditions of work with sources of physical factors affecting people", adopted by the Government on January 25, 2012. The current new decree # 26 (Ministry of Energy) sets emission standards for dioxins/furans; however, no monitoring and control system over unintentional POPs exists in the country, except for MACs/emission limits. Further, amendments have been proposed by the project in terms of a law on introducing requirements on POPs monitoring in environment into existing regulatory framework associated with the implementation of the Djasyl Damu (Green Economy) National Development Programme.

description.narrative: Sectoral technical guidelines updated to include the issue of priority POPs, including sampling and analysis methods

comment.narrative: Guidelines and action plans are being drafted on the sectors related to POPs waste and PCBs, under the UNDP PCB project under Zhasyl Damu (Green Growth) initiative.
Technical guidelines and action plans on POPs are submitted for approval by relevant state bodies.
Planned in future reporting cycles.

description.narrative: Capacity building programme (trainings) and consultations for involved stakeholders developed and implemented on POPs related risks, POPs monitoring, institutional roles and responsibilities, POPs control legislation benchmarks and enforcement

comment.narrative: No national training held on new POPs, developments in the Stockholm Convention and NIP update guidelines; Currently prevailing insufficient knowledge on new POPs, their risks and control measures and approaches
At least, two (2) complementary workshops held Sixty (60) stakeholders participated in workshops Results of stakeholder consultations NIP update formulated

Four (4) regional training workshops were conducted on issues related to the management of POPs, including new POPs in three pilot provinces of the country for territorial municipal, health, sanitary and environmental control administrations, including hospitals, as well as for central authorities and industrial associations (300 participants in total). Overall, six (6) consultation meetings held at the indicated four (4) general workshops, and two (2) at the premises of Ministry of Energy during September –November 2014. NIP update for new POPs was approved by order of the Minister of Energy of the Republic of Kazakhstan 228 dated 30.12.2014 and submitted to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to be presented to the Secretariat for the Stockholm Convention. Activity completed.

description.narrative: National Implementation Plan (NIP) on Stockholm Convention obligations with inclusion of new POPs reviewed and updated, with elaboration of specific action plans on new POPs.

comment.narrative: The Government is carrying out several non-coordinated actions on POPs (update of inventories on pesticidal POPs in 5 regions, PCB management, inventory and partial disposal, planning better control of uPOPs, improving of existing regulations).
Final draft of the NIP completed and circulated for review within the main stakeholders. Updated NIP submitted for approval to the Government, approved and submitted to the Secretariat.

During the reporting period, the project team has been working on updating the NIP in regards of the introduction of new POPs. A national contractor firm (of 4 national experts) was selected to organize the data collection and analysis process, based on guidance form international consultant. Inventory on new POPs has been completed, while work on unintentional POPs, and planned work on updated inventory on POPs pesticides are still ongoing. Data on new POPs have been captured in the NIP update document which was transmitted to the Stockholm Convention secretariat. The updated National Implementation Plan on new POPs for 2015-2028 was approved by decree of Ministry of Energy # 228 dated 30/12/2014. It was submitted to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to be presented to the Secretariat for the Stockholm Convention.

description.narrative: Improved institutional coordination on chemical MEAs
Review and better alignment of ministerial functions on implementation of Conventions’ obligations

comment.narrative: No or very fragmented institutional structure overseeing chemicals MEAs Lack of common knowledge on synergies between chemical MEAs
Roadmap in place for joint coordination of MEAs Draft regulation to enforce selected recommendations is in place
Planned in future reporting cycles

description.narrative: Establishment of coordination mechanisms to support synergistic implementation of Stockholm, Rotterdam and Basel Conventions and established framework (system) for monitoring, accountancy and reporting on the implementation of the Stockholm, Basel and Rotterdam conventions in Kazakhstan

comment.narrative: No conceptual understanding (strategy) on the synergism and collaborative operation of responsible parties No or very fragmented institutional structure overseeing chemicals MEAs No formal coordination mechanism established for synergistic implementation of MEAs No TOR and mandate of the mechanism is in existence No formal central monitoring on reporting obligations is maintained to assess quality of MEA implementation Data collection challenges to ensure better reporting

Draft legislation supporting establishment of the coordinating mechanism submitted for review and approval Temporary (with GEF/UNDP project’s help) and fixed (Government) budgets for operation of the MEA mechanism defined and proposal for financing submitted to MoF Monitoring system forms part of the prepared draft legislation on the MEA coordinating mechanism Draft strategic concept and action plan are in place
Planned in future reporting cycles

description.narrative: Capacity of government authorities on implementation of chemical conventions improved Improved data collection and chemical review processes for decision making and control improvements on the import and use of new dangerous chemical substances

comment.narrative: Lack of legal framework for cooperation among key stakeholders No previous training on synergies and MEA implementation held Data collection challenges to ensure better reporting No conceptual understanding (strategy) on the synergism and collaborative operation of responsible parties No action plan in place to support operation of the MEA coordinating mechanism
Draft legislation supporting establishment of the coordinating mechanism submitted for review and approval Received capacity is applied in decision-making forums

description.narrative: Mercury assessment implemented, national consultations held to identify priorities for actions and capacity building on mercury risks carried out
Capacity building programme (trainings) for involved stakeholders developed and implemented on mercury risks, inventories, sources, data tracking

comment.narrative: No previous larger scale efforts applied to build capacity of related stakeholders on mercury negotiations, mercury convention, mercury associated risks etc Limitations in the scale of stakeholder activities on mercury, with exception to Ust-Kamenogorsk WB’s programme on decontamination
Capacity building program (trainings) for involved stakeholders completed.

An inter-agency working group on mercury management, involving Ministries of Foreign Affairs, Industry and Trade, Health, Economy and Social Development, and representatives of industrial associations, was established in January 2015 to support consultations and decision-making on joining the Minamata Convention. Based on a specialized capacity building program which was developed by the project (on mercury risks, inventorying, source profiling, national database), four (4) general workshops were organized during fall time 2014: three (3) in pilot provinces, and one (1) central workshop in the capital city, with 300 people participated, mainly from territorial and central administrations (municipal - Akimats, health, sanitary, environmental), and representatives of industrial associations. Materials of the assessment of mercury impact on human health conducted by the World Health Organization (www.who.int/ceh) have been used in the preparation of training courses and workshops The Ministry of Energy in cooperation with local authorities continues to work to remediate a historical mercury hotspot in Pavlodar city (population of 352,693 as of start of 2014), and a WB-supported project in Karaganda was to complete on Nura river contamination.

description.narrative: Mercury situation in Kazakhstan assessed in coordinated manner jointly with UNEP

comment.narrative: No national mercury assessment made, except in form of waste product No database on sources and mercury releases is in existence No full understanding of scale impact on human health

Assessment of country’s mercury sources, releases, contaminated sites and priority areas for mercury control completed The country’s baseline data is established. Information made available through database and open access web-site

Project team announced a call for services and sub-contracted same contractor as for the NIP update – the consultancy firm “Centre for Facilitation of Sustainable Development”. An initial assessment of the existing capacity for the management of mercury has been carried out.
A basic assessment of the availability of mercury thermometers in inpatient health facilities in the 3 pilot regions was completed through questionnaires in 2013. Data were used in drafting healthcare management plans. The initial mercury assessment is now underway, and the project will be in position in next reporting cycles to provide an overview of the national situation with Mercury. It is now believed, that due to the size of the country and current experience with parallel ongoing projects on mercury remediation, additional substantial resources will be needed to fully assess mercury emitters once identified. Based on the initial work, main sources of mercury pollution have been identified, and a list of companies engaged in recycling and treatment of mercury waste has been prepared Preparatory works for the monitoring of mercury in the environment are performed in cooperation with the uPOPs monitoring sub-component of the project (RECETOX).

description.narrative: Outline of National mercury reduction plan developed

comment.narrative: No national mercury assessment made, except in form of waste product No mercury action plan in place outlining priority action and setting budgetary allocations

Required data collected and analysed, and discussed in stakeholder forums Priorities identified and agreed with stakeholders Draft National Mercury Reduction plan is formally reviewed and cleared by relevant line Ministries and submitted for final approval.

Inventory activity is ongoing. Taking into account the policy of Kazakhstan to reduce the number of national policy documents, a decision was made during the Inception workshop instead of preparing a draft Mercury Reduction Plan to prepare recommendations for the reduction of mercury. This work is planned. Project team participated in a regional IPEN meeting in Central Asia on public participation in chemical safety issues in EECCA countries. Following that meeting, and local consultations, a justification concept on Minamata convention ratification drafted and is prepared for submission to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs for review.

description.narrative: Public awareness raising campaigns on mercury risks conducted

comment.narrative: Low awareness of sources of mercury in consumer goods and consequences of their improper disposal.
Remaining 50% of activities designed in the awareness campaign accomplished

During 2014, four (4) national workshops were held where mercury issues were discussed (on par with the general POPs matters) in three (3) pilot provinces and the capital. Three hundred (300) stakeholder representatives from government, health sector and industry improved their awareness on mercury management aspects and safety.

description.narrative: Sound health-care waste management through uPOPs and mercury reduction approaches are demonstrated in 2-3 regions of the country
Review of national policies and update of HCWM regulatory framework and road map

comment.narrative: No comprehensive conceptual note on improving HCWM policies is in existence No currently established emission standard for waste incineration (POPs, heavy metals). No legal provisions exist, except minimum temperature standard for healthcare waste incineration. No technical standards set for hazardous healthcare waste treatment, including non-combustion methods. No current requirements defined for waste management plans and country budget does not consider non-incineration technologies for wider replication. Public procurement rules do not include provisions on EPP (procured products can still contain heavy metals and other harmful substances), and the lowest price criterion is the main foundation. Reporting systems (on waste amounts, tracking and monitoring) are underdeveloped

Legislative improvements (through amendments in the EcoCode) are submitted for final approval by the Government. Technical standard for hazardous healthcare waste treatment, including non-combustion methods, is established in close consultations and forms a part of legislative improvements Public procurement rules are amended and EPP criteria are set Awareness raising workshops and media reports (at least, 3 complementary workshops for medical and private sectors, and 10 media reports) National reporting to POPs convention improved

An assessment of the current legislation on healthcare waste handling issues has been completed. Project further evaluated the system of state cooperation in terms of accounting and disposal of healthcare waste; and assessed the environmental and sanitary-epidemiological requirements for healthcare waste handling. Gaps have been revealed in the type of statistical information is being prepared and collected by the National Statistical Committee on HCW area. Various formats for data reporting are used in different provinces of the country – some hospitals report in kgs, tons or in unit measures. In this respect, it is planned to develop proposals for changes in the national statistical system and industry reporting, with one unified reporting mechanism and format to ensure consistency and aid decision-making process in future. Based on the regional healthcare waste management plans prepared for the three (3) pilot regions, the project will prepare, after pilot investment part with new technologies has been demonstrated, a summary report for the health/sanitary authorities to request consideration to replicate these pilots on a wider scale in the country. This will form a basis for the development of a unified national concept on healthcare waste management. Further, after that step, project plans to incorporate its recommendations into a national municipal waste management plan which will raise the status of medical wastes to that strategic level. The current decree # 26 of January 2015 (Ministry of Energy), prepared on the basis of the project’s intervention, sets emission standards for dioxins/furans. Additionally, amendments to the Environmental Code (regarding emission standards for dioxins/furans) have been proposed by the project team. The previous governmental resolution of 2007 which set basic principles related to hazardous waste management, after legal reform, was transposed into a Ministry of Energy decree of November 28, 2014. This decree listed disposal technologies, on the basis of EU references, which covered wastewater discharges, releases from mining activities. It is now planned to introduce changes to the list of BAT and incorporate information on technologies related to healthcare waste disposal. Proposals for amendments to the legislation on public procurement have been prepared and include environmental considerations, to be added to standard cost considerations in the legislation. This work is done jointly with a parallel GEF-UNDP project on energy-efficiency which deals in part with mercury waste coming out of CFL lamps. These amendments are hoped for introduction into a main law on public procurement in 2016. Finally on legislation, as of May 4, 2015 project introduced amendments to previous governmental resolutions related to sanitary rules as applied to hospital operation. These authorize the use of needle cutters, and of alternative non-combustion waste disposal methods. Four (4) regional training workshops were conducted on issues related to the management of POPs, including new POPs in three pilot provinces (300 participants in total). The project made an economic analysis of the existing healthcare waste disposal system as well as those of alternative disposal methods proposed by the project. Certain maintenance issues were faced by owners of previously supplied non-incineration equipment (microwave technology with embedded shredder) due to frequent failures of the cutting blade – replacement costs are high. These problems were voiced during workshops. This material, and the establishment of non-combustion centers for treatment of medical waste in three pilot areas, will create a good foundation for future development of such system on a wider scale in the country.

description.narrative: Development of Regional HCWM Management Plan in selected provinces

comment.narrative: Baseline situation indicates no concerted action with adherence to BAT/BEP in medical sector Sector is fragmented with disorganized players with no systemic approach to resolving uPOPs, mercury issues and inappropriate HCWM practices. No specifically tailored action plan exists, and quality data is missing. No previous capacity building and demonstration of BAT/BEP to reduce uPOPs and mercury releases implemented
The Management Plan is adopted, and further actions and investments scheduled Roadmap to support its implementation is approved by participating stakeholders

Based on technical advice from international expert, the project team had designed Healthcare Waste Management Plans for three selected pilot areas (Kostanay, Astana, and Ust-Kamenogorsk). These plans include description of currently used healthcare waste management system, proposed alternative ways to improve practices through waste segregation (including the use of needle cutters to reduce accidents at work, and separate out plastic parts for disinfection). It is expected that these plans will be introduced into the strategic regional development plans later in 2015 to ensure they are put into practical implementation. An assessment of the waste generation volumes and decontamination of infectious healthcare waste across the country as a whole has been completed. And, in selected pilot areas this assessment has been implemented in 16 regions of the country, and in all state-funded hospitals and medical facilities. 154 medical facilities (2,761 beds) were assessed in the pilot regions. The project further plans for preparation of recommendations to improve the reporting system of waste generation levels, demonstrate replacement of current basic incinerators for healthcare waste treatment with the alternative non-incineration technology, and of mercury thermometers with mercury-free alternatives (electronic measurement devices). Data collection and analysis with regards to the treatment technologies for infectious healthcare waste in the pilot regions has been concluded. All incineration plants and plants processing infectious healthcare waste in the pilot regions have been identified and mapped.

description.narrative: Pilot HCWM projects in selected hospitals, including phase-out of mercury containing thermometers

comment.narrative: No target hospitals for pilots defined before baseline assessment. Waste minimization and segregation at source not practiced No alternative (non-mercury) thermometers and alternative product substitution demonstrated No model facilities (with individual action plans) pilot sustainable BAT/BEP and reduction in waste generation and uPOPs/mercury releases BAT/BEP are not up taken on a larger scale Overall waste management system is weak

BAT/BEP (uPOPs and mercury reduction) policies are implemented and targets recorded. Mercury thermometers are replaced by electronic devices, with resulting mercury waste safely handled Health facilities dispose IHCW in non-combustion installation. Evaluation and documentation of practical results (inclusive of waste amounts minimized, uPOPs/mercury releases reduced) in conjunction with Outcome 4

Three pilot areas have been identified (Ust-Kamenogorsk East Kazakhstan oblast, Kostanai oblast and Astana city). Eight (8) pilot hospitals have been selected: Astana (Research Institute of Traumatology and Orthopedics, Central Road Hospital), East-Kazakhstan oblast (CSE on EAR "Center of Mother and Child"; CSE on EAR Ust-Kamenogorsk city hospital 1, CSE on EAR "Central District Hospital of Katonkaragay District"), and Kostanay oblast (CSE on EAR Kostanai Drug Dispensary; SCCE “Oblast Hospital”; SCCE “Zhitigarinskaya CDH”. A baseline assessment for each pilot hospital has been conducted using the individual Rapid Assessment (I-RAT) tool developed under the Global Medical Waste project as well as the "Guidelines for conducting a baseline assessment of an experienced medical institution". A registry (database) of hospitals in pilot regions has been created, and collection of data has been carried out in all hospitals of the pilot regions (154 facilities - 2,761 beds). During reporting period, the project team assessed at the pilot sites their methods for healthcare waste treatment; and determined, based on guidance from assigned international expert with field visits, processing capacities (and design: with or w/o steam generator, shredder) required for each pilot hospital/healthcare facility. ITB for procurement of non-incineration technologies (six 100 kg/h autoclaves, two 20 kg/h autoclaves for distant districts, and 1 more potential 20 kg/h autoclave if in case budget allows) are planned for formulation for the second half of 2015 to supply technology in 2016. Healthcare waste management (HCWM) plans have been developed for the three (3) pilot regions, and project is actively working on getting these HCWM plans approved and the inclusion of main indicators/priorities into the strategic regional development documents for the target pilot areas. A tender for the procurement of mercury-free thermometers will be soon announced. It is planned to procure 15,000 units of these electronic substitutes.

description.narrative: Establishment of HCW treatment centres in selected sites

comment.narrative: Overall waste management system is weak Health facilities have no access to organised waste treatment system or the waste is incinerated in installations not fulfilling BEP/BAT criteria. No non-incineration technologies procured and adopted to support new management system in selected regions Waste disposal and transportation of waste in peripheral areas (away from municipal or capital centers) is disadvantaged due to high price Low quality of service provision results in additional sanitary risks

HCW treatment centres successfully operate at preliminary planned capacity (950 tons per annum). Pricing policies implemented at target groups of stakeholders and service providers Applicable recommendations on possible pricing criteria proposed for legislative amendments Waste reduction amounts and uPOPs reductions are measured and reported on
Tenders to open in the second half of 2015. Activities planned in the next reporting cycles. Project plans the development of a proposal for setting tariffs on safe disposal of health-care wastes.

description.narrative: Linkages between sound HCWM practices and minimization of uPOPs and mercury demonstrated through training and awareness raising programmes
Development and dissemination of BAT/BEP technical guidelines and general awareness raising

comment.narrative: No technical BAT/BEP guidelines in line with international benchmarks (SC, BC) for uPOPs/mercury release reduction and HCW management in place No guidance materials for data collection and processing Hospitals do not have guidance materials in support of trainings and daily safe practices General awareness on uPOPs/mercury and management is limited

Technical guidelines approved and printed (legislative support to back guidelines proposed) Hospitals receive materials for application in daily work Project team participates in scientific medical conferences (at least, 2), public campaigns (media reports, at least 5, interviews, at least, 3), Zhasyl Damuu programme discussions and rountables National curricula updated

Introduction of changes to the existing list of best-available technologies (BAT) for treatment and disposal of healthcare waste is planned. Current legislation that refers to BAT technologies excludes this area of work, and will be amended in 2016 with a new list. As part of South-South cooperation and experience exchange, project team participated in the GIZ-funded international conference for Central Asia, Afghanistan and other countries on biological hazard safety and protection in the neighboring, Kyrgyzstan in October 2014, shared its experience and exchanged with the Kyrgyzstan team (a parallel GEF-UNDP project on HCWM) on best practices. The project team has started initial planning for design and development of a training module on healthcare waste management which will be discussed in the Ministry of health in future for application in medical colleges and universities. Further progress in this area will be reported in future reporting cycles.

description.narrative: Development of national training programs on uPOPs/mercury risks and sound HCWM, partnership with stakeholders and national replication of BAT/BEP demonstration

comment.narrative: Currently, no HCW management training program exists as established by MPH No manuals specifying details of waste management in a hospital setting exist Limited in scope debriefings are practiced for new hospital staff, but no regular capacity building is in place or regularly planned by hospital facilities

Training carried in two demonstration regions for major health facilities, regional administration, and waste management service providers. Training carried in 12 regions for major health facilities, and regional administration and integrated into national training system Training program adopted and replicated by health institutions. Media follows the initiative

Four (4) regional training workshops were conducted on issues related to the management of POPs, including new POPs in three pilot provinces of the country for territorial municipal, health, sanitary and environmental control administrations, including hospitals, as well as for central authorities and industrial associations (300 participants in total). Three (3) posts in online newspapers, and two (2) broadcasts on national TV; one (1) article was posted in a newspaper Kostanay Agro (one of pilot provinces), and in last edition of 2014 of a national magazine “Industry of Kazakhstan”.

description.narrative: Monitoring, learning, adaptive feedback, outreach, and evaluation.
M&E and adaptive management applied to project in response to needs, mid-term evaluation findings with lessons learned extracted.

comment.narrative: No Monitoring and Evaluation system No evaluation of project output and outcomes
Final evaluation report ready in the end of project

Project activities, work plan and budget for the 2014/2015 were discussed and approved during the board meetings which took place in April 2014; July 2014; and January 2015. Mid-term evaluation will be planned at time of the second PIR reporting exercise in line with UNDP-GEF Evaluation Office’s recommendations. As part of South-South cooperation and experience exchange, project team participated in the GIZ-funded international conference for Central Asia, Afghanistan and other countries on biological hazard safety and protection in the neighboring, Kyrgyzstan in October 2014, shared its experience and exchanged with the Kyrgyzstan team (a parallel GEF-UNDP project on HCWM) on best practices. Project team also participated in a regional IPEN meeting in Central Asia (held in Almaty, Kazakhstan) on public participation in chemical safety issues in EECCA countries.

description.narrative: Improving sustainability of the Protected Area system in desert ecosystems through promotion of biodiversity-compatible livelihoods in and around Protected Areas
The project objective is to enhance the sustainability of protected areas in globally important desert and semi-desert ecosystems
independent political entity
Environment - policy, planning and administration

To enhance the sustainability of protected areas in globally important desert and semi-desert ecosystems by expanding their geographic coverage, promoting a landscape approach, and supporting biodiversity-compatible livelihoods in and around PAs.
Coverage of underrepresented Southern desert in the PA System of Kazakhstan

comment.narrative: 1,591,800 ha (5.3% of ecological zone)

By 2015 coverage of Southern desert in PA system increases by 2,682,032 ha (8.9% of the ecological zone). This increase comes from the following: Establishment of 1 new PA (Mangistau State Reserved Zone) covering 2,676,262 ha, Expansion of 1 existing PA (Barsakelmes State Nature Reserve) by 5,770 ha. By 2020 coverage of Southern desert in PA system increases by approximately 970,000 ha (3.2% of the ecological zone). This increase comes from: Expansion of 1 existing PA (Ustyurt State Nature Reserve) by approximately 220,000 ha, Establishment of a wildlife corridor between Barsakelmes and Ustyurt PAs of approximately 750,000 ha

1,591,800 ha (5.3% of ecological zone) as in the baseline The following activities have been initiated/completed by the project to ensure the achievement of the EoP target:
-Plan of land boundaries allotment for establishment of Mangistau protected area of total area 2,600,000 ha is being approved by local government (akimat) of Mangistau Oblast.
-Works on approval of land use design and feasibility study (TEO) to expand Barsakelmes reserve’s area at local government (akimat) level of Kyzylorda Oblast were performed.
- dialogue platform was created to openly discuss issues related to adding 23,000 ha of the Syrdaria river delta to the Barsakelmes reserve.
-scientific background report (ENO) for expansion of the Ustyurt reserve’s area to 704,000 ha (2.3% of ecological zone) was developed. ENO was approved by the authorized body, report on the positive state ecological appraisal was obtained. The feasibility study (TEO) to expand the reserve’s area is being developed.
-field studies on habitation of rare ungulate species of animals between Barsakelmes and Ustyurt PAs were conducted. Habitation and animal migration maps were drawn for three routes with total length of 841 km. The results of scientific works will be used to establish the proposed ecological corridor.

description.narrative: Coverage of underrepresented Mountain-valley subtype desert in the PA System of Kazakhstan

comment.narrative: 99,704 ha (3.3% of ecological zone)

By 2015 coverage of Mountain-valley subtype desert in PA system increases by 1,602,504 ha (53.4% of the ecological zone). This increase comes from the following:
- Establishment of 1 new PA (Ile-Balkhash State Nature Reserve) covering 442,296 ha
- Expansion of 1 existing PA (Altyn Yemel State National Nature Park) by 460,208 ha
- Establishment of a wildlife corridor between Altyn Yemel and Ile-Balkhash PAs of 700,000 ha
By 2020 coverage of Mountain-valley subtype desert in PA system increases by approximately 30,000 ha (1% of the ecological zone). This increase comes from the following:
- Establishment of 1 new PA (Arganaty) covering approximately 30,000 ha

Scheme development for land-use planning of Aral Syrdaria (Aral and Kazaly districts) and Ile-Balkhash (Balkhash district) project areas is being completed.
Based on identified priorities of socio-economic development and nature-resource potential, land-use planning will create a basis for sustainable land management. Expected total area for land-use planning is 13,000,000 ha.

comment.narrative: 0 ha

For the reporting period the current situation for 2 delta lakes was assessed: Aidarkol (Aral -Syrdaria) and Kelte (ile-Balkhash). Hydrological studies on detection of optimum water level, needed for their restoration are being carried out.

description.narrative: Number of hectares of riparian & saksaul forests under sustainable management

comment.narrative: 0 ha

1,500 ha
For the reporting period the state of saxaul and tugai forests was assessed, ways of conservation and restoration of such forests were identified.
To restore saxaul forests in the Aral-Syrdaria region, a project on establishment of forest nursery for saxaul and other hardy-shrub species is being implemented. As a result, for the reporting period 1,500 ha of saxaul were planted in the Aral pilot area.
In the Ile-Balkhash region, a pilot project on conservation of the relict Asiatic poplar (turanga) small woods covering an area of 1,800 ha is being implemented.

description.narrative: Quality and quantity of vegetation cover in rangelands in 3 rural districts

comment.narrative: Hectares of land with significant signs of soil erosion caused by overgrazing in selected plots[1] [1] Baseline to be estimated at the beginning of the project once monitoring sites are identified and primary data are collected.
Reduction of the size of the area heavily affected by soil erosion by at least 15% in the Ile Balkhash area and 20% in the Aral Syrdarya target area

The Project implements pilot projects in two rural areas. Total area of degraded pastures is 11, 000 ha. Activities are being implemented to improve their quality and demonstrate sustainable distant-pasture cattle rearing practices. Monitoring sites were selected and initial indicators of the land degradation factor were identified in pasture plots “Dala Karatay” and “Nausha Bulak”:
- Nausha Bulak (5,000 ha) – the land degradation factor is 30% of total monitoring area;
- Dala Karatay (6,000 ha) – the land degradation factor is 35% of total monitoring area.
The quality indicator variability will be assessed after the achievement of envisaged outcomes of the pilot projects.

description.narrative: Presence of plant species which negatively affect the function of distant rangelands

comment.narrative: Hectares of distant rangelands with significant signs of natural succession due to under grazing[1] [1] Same as previous footnote
Unwanted plant species in at least 4 rangeland monitoring plots are less than 5% surface coverage

Initial indicators of unwanted plant species (bitterling, peganum) coverage were identified in selected monitoring pasture plots:
- Nausha Bulak pasture plot (5,000 ha) - the area covered by unwanted plants at the beginning of pilot project implementation comprise 750 ha or 15% of total area.
- Dala Karatay plot (6,000 ha) - initial indicator of unwanted plants is 550 ha or 9.1% of total area.
The quality indicator variability will be assessed after the achievement of envisage outcomes of the pilot projects.

$1600

The indicator variability will be assessed after the achievement of expected outcomes of the pilot projects.

description.narrative: Number of farmer associations that use the experiences of this project as a model

comment.narrative: No projects which use participatory bottom-up approaches in the target areas
At least 15 farmer associations or rural consumer cooperatives in the Aral Syrdarya target area and 25 in the Ile Balkhash area use the experience of this project as a model.

More than 20 farms in the Aral-Syrdaria and Ile-Balkhash project areas, as well as local authorities, NGOs, scientific institutions are informed on the options and benefits of green technology application in the irrigated agriculture and distant-pasture cattle rearing.
As a result, support was granted for implementation, demonstration and replication of recommended approaches by already 3 farms.

comment.narrative: 2 by project end

To implement the payments for ecosystem services (PES) mechanism the following work stages were identified:
1) identification of ecosystem services (determinations of key providers and consumers of ecosystem services (2015);
2) economic assessment of ecosystem services (2016);
3) holding negotiations with consumers of ecosystem services, development of PES Agreements and signing contracts with consumers of ecosystem services (2016-2017).
During the reporting period works on identification of ecosystem services in the Ile-Balkhash and Aral-Syrdaria project areas were conducted.
Providers and consumers of ecosystem services were identified. A map of ecosystem services is being elaborated.

730 registered land users located near pilot PAs were identified.
16 registered land users (2%) in three project areas already obtained access to the project's microcredit funds through a Microcredit program “Eco-Damu”, which is administered by the Financing Fund for Agricultural Support (FFAS).

description.narrative: Supporting Kazakhstan’s Transition to a Green Economy model
policy, planning and administration
Contribute to the long-term environmental sustainability and inclusive economic development of Kazakhstan through supporting the country's transition to a Green Economy model.

comment.narrative: In the follow-up to the Rio+20 process on sustainable development, Kazakhstan took a landmark decision to transition towards a sustainable Green Economy Concept, aimed at implementing a completely new development paradigm with particular focus on the water sector.

Inception report development and endorsement, view of economic instruments and MPWI bussnes models, demonstration projects in key sectors , form a pool of pilot projects. Multi stakeholder dialogue on pilot projects, pilot projects concepts developing

During 2015 Inception workshop was conductead and inceptionreport was developed adn approved by donor, NGOs Grant programme was launched, grants Agreements are signed, 3 pilot concepts were developed and approved by key stakeholders, workshop was organized for the reccomendations collection form key stakeholders and detailed work plans on pilot projects implementation developed,review of economic instruments and MPWI bussnes models started

Interim report of grant programme implementation, contracts for 4 pilot projects are signed, starting of pilot projects implementation, to prepare report on economic instruments in two sectors of Kazakhstan, to prepare a plan for Balkhash Alakol bassin saving, workshop and report on green indicators, review on dams in Kazakhstan

Under the pilot activities, on the territory of greenhouse facility, Training Center for Green Technologies has been established to train farmers, students, master's degree students, entrepreneurs and others. The trainees will be provided with practical skills required for agrarian sector, and will also study elements of the most promising energy and resource saving technologies that will help improve methods and ways of growing vegetables in a protected soil, and effectively use heat and energy, natural resources, and ways of provision of fresh vegetables to population round the year. Due to the grant program, 14 NGOs were supported to implement projects related to green economy. Overall, water consumption for irrigation at the pilot sites have been reduced 40%. Energy efficiency rose up to 20%, due to technologies harvesting of farmers increased up to 20%, water supply improved for 700 residents; 8 schools have access to clean water and 6 social buildings have access to hot water. 7 green business models have been developed and supported within the project through contest among youth, such as Water in AUL and Startup Bolashak. Green economy elements were integrated into the Balkhash-Alakol Basin Saving and Management Plan. This will enable to improve water quality and water disposal management of the Basin.

comment.narrative: 1. Land use planning does not account for ecosystem values, leading to ecosystem degradation 2. Absence of advanced practices on pasture logging/watering; 3. Inadequate policy and legal framework to support a transformation to SLM 4. Traditional subsidies in agriculture prioritize productivity and take no heed of ecosystem carrying capacity 5. Limited and inefficient investments in pasture and maintenance of productive landscapes

1. Inception workshop 2. The national project team are in place 3. Assessment of national regulatory document on agricultural system of subsidy 4. Development of methodology for conducting inventory of pastures and crop land capacities in five target regions 5. Prioritization of implementation activities per each target regions

1. Conducted one inception workshop 2. Project personnel are on board (Project manager, Project admin assistant) 3. Produced conducted report on agricultural subsidies in Kazakhstan 4. Produced methodology for pasture land inventory analyses based on the East Kazakhstan regions as one of the pilot project areas. 5. Identified five priority topics per ach target zones on demonstration plots. (fruit and vegetable growing for Almaty region, Wheat, crop diversification and precise agriculture for Akmola regions, Pastoral livestock breeding for East Kazakhstan regions, Crop husbandry and diversification, Pasture and precise agriculture for Kostanay region, Soil desalinization, crop diversification and organic farming for Kyzylorda region and Wheat, crop diversification and precise agriculture for North Kazakhstan regions.

At least 2 ILUP are developed One methodology is developed to promote pasture land inventories. At least 5 new advanced agro technologies are introduced on productive agro landscapes. One pasture crops seed farming enterprise is established. At least 3 new effective agro effective agro incentive modules and mechanism to promote productive land scape management are introduced. At least one inter-ministerial task force group to promote the development of ILUP is established and functional. At least one policy and legal document harmonized to promote the issues of effective productive landscape management.
